intro: Periomphale gaultherioides, commonly known as the Alaska snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the northern regions of North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its white, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in open, rocky areas and is adapted to cold climates. Its leaves are finely divided and resemble those of the related genus Gaultheria. Periomphale gaultherioides is often found in alpine tundra and is a symbol of the harsh yet beautiful Arctic environment.
